Have you checked the memory consumption?

Memory isn't really 'leaked'. It's released to a pool. The pool will only be emptied when an allocation returns out of memory.
You can run this forever and it won't fail with OOM.

Some update: 
when batch size > 1, it works great.
But if multiple threads invoke with batch size = 1, it runs really slow.
Seems due to OpenMP's design.
I have implemented multi-process framework as a workaround, close this.
@cyq130 The problem is caused by lib name mismatch. I'm trying to figure out why it somehow happens.
you can find a older version of make_list.py here [https://github.com/imistyrain/mxnet-mr/blob/master/make_list.py](https://github.com/imistyrain/mxnet-mr/blob/master/make_list.py)

@piiswrong Actually the rcnn example is killed by the os because it used all the memory(128g). I think this is because the allocation algorithm, i.e. https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/b7df20d6bea07a191552c89e4b14021eeedd5504/src/storage/pooled_storage_manager.h#L52 .

It seems this line looks for free space in the pool according to the **exact** size, while in practice there are a lot of different but similar sizes allocated. For example, in the rcnn example, the images are all resized to a shorter size of 600px, so basically the sizes are (~600, ~600), but they are **all different sizes**, so this leads to a collapse of the program, since (600, 600), (600,601), (600,602)...(600, xxxx) will all be individually allocated. I think this part needs some refactoring...

Related: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1176 and https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1952

For now I'll try to add a threshold, which is removed in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/commit/b7df20d6bea07a191552c89e4b14021eeedd5504

It looks like some kind of memory deallocation issue. I ran Miguel's code above several times without a problem (set devices to one GPU). Then I ran the code starting below the assignment of conv0. This crashes the R GUI. 
So, every time you need to reassign conv0; otherwise the program crashes.

After I post this issue, the report came out surprisingly. Close the issue.

Now I get it after I checked the source code. The evaluation metric would only report when you do have multiple batches in an epoch: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/721fd800be0dab51c594bf956e0188a78a8a7a70/python/mxnet/callback.py#L78-L93

I'm also having all these problems trying to compile the latest version of mxnet.

I don't see a valid reason to close this issue since the bug clearly still exists.
I'll list a roadmap for scala pkg this weekend.
Thanks
My mistake, the program can be terminated

I also encountered this problem. As @neodooth suggested, reverting `pooled_storage_manager.h` and `storage.cc` to the status before https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/commit/b7df20d6bea07a191552c89e4b14021eeedd5504 successfully prevented out-of-memory from occuring again.
I guess one can set `kPoolThreshold` to a larger value than `4096 * 1024 * 1024` if a larger RAM is available.
use make/osx.mk instead of make/config.mk if you are using make. Follow the mac installation instructions, not the linux one
Make sure your mac actually has a nvidia gpu. Most macs doesn't

In bn we need to use the global stats from training phase in testing according to the original paper. 

Could you check that in the saved model the BN stats (namely, the auxiliary variables) are not nan?

Also, could you confirm that it works in GPU mode?
